pdgm.pdgmnote: WedekindC1985 p. 124. The verb comehas both a suppletive and a nonsuppletive form
Sasse-Straube1977 pp. 254-255. HudsonG1976 pp. 255-256. Note Sasse-Straube:Von den Demonstrativa sind nur die Formen der ,,hier’’ –Deixis (,dieser’ etc.) belegt– far deixis form is from Hudson.
WedekindC1985 pp. 133-139 Note discussions of consonant assimilations for causative –s- pp. 133-136,for benefactive pp. 136-137.

WedekindC1985 p. 117. In the suffix,The –I -u forms are Perfect forms where relevance of the action to the Present is maintained. The –oo forms are Past forms used almost exclusively in narrative discourse.
Sasse-Straube1977 pp. 257. Der Infinitive hat ohne Ausahme die Endung –a:
Sasse-Straube1977 pp. 257. Vielen Verben steht ein VerbAdj mit dem Suffix –anee oder einfach –ee zur Seite:.
WedekindC1985 p. 114. Defective forms:for me/us to have gone
WedekindC1985 p. 121. Cf. also p. 115 and Sasse-Straube1977,p. 256
WedekindC1985 p. 125. [Not clear whether this is simply a negation of simplePerf,or of anything perfect/past.]
WedekindC1985 p. 121. Cf. also p. 115 and Sasse-Straube1977,p. 256

WedekindC1985 p. 119. Different vowel suffixes esp. in 1st and 2nd sg. hayy- wish and yeɗ- be,exist belong to this class. yeɗ- also has past form but present meaning (common for verbs of existence in Ethiopian languages).
WedekindC1985 p. 123. (cf. also p. 115). (33) Full forms would be,for instance:haani maru-waa let me go!,haani maru-waa-see let me go!

WedekindC1985 p. 120,paradigms #23 [mar-]and #24 [hayy-]. Author states:The first of the following imperfect paradigms is used when no further context is given. So every form in this paradigm is fully acceptable as a complete,well-formed utterance.[Not certain how to interpret this.]
